channel.title: History Explorer Podcast
channel.itunes:subtitle: from the Smithsonian Institution's National Museum of American History
channel.itunes:author: Smithsonian National Museum of American History
channel.itunes:summary: Behind the scenes at the Smithsonian Institution's National Museum of American History, staff members are conducting exciting, original research and collecting objects-both iconic and seemingly mundane-to tell compelling stories of American history. This podcast takes listeners along on their intellectual adventures. Along the way, we seek to expose the process of historical inquiry and present thought-provoking stories. Accompanying this series are standards-aligned teacher guides and Smithsonian images for classroom use.
channel.description: Behind the scenes at the Smithsonian Institution's National Museum of American History, staff members are conducting exciting, original research and collecting objects-both iconic and seemingly mundane-to tell compelling stories of American history. This podcast takes listeners along on their intellectual adventures. Along the way, we seek to expose the process of historical inquiry and present thought-provoking stories. Accompanying this series are standards-aligned teacher guides and Smithsonian images for classroom use.

item.title: Exploring the Electric Guitar
item.description: Learn about the invention of this fascinating instrument as Exhibition Program Manager Monica Smith discusses the history of the guitar and those involved in its creation. Includes accompanying resources for classroom use.
item.itunes:author: Smithsonian National Museum of American History
item.itunes:subtitle: Monica Smith discusses the invention of America's favorite instrument.
item.itunes:summary: Learn about the invention of this fascinating instrument as Exhibition Program Manager Monica Smith discusses the history of the guitar and those involved in its creation. Includes accompanying resources for classroom use.
item.itunes:keywords: invention, electric guitar, music, fender, gibson, guitar, instrument, history, American history, museum, Smithsonian

item.title: The Sioux City Ghosts
item.description: Listen as archivist Reuben Jackson discusses the Sioux City Ghosts, an African-American traveling baseball team and swing band from the 1930's. Includes accompanying resources for classroom use.
item.itunes:author: Smithsonian National Museum of American History
item.itunes:subtitle: Reuben Jackson talks about an eclectic group of musicians/athletes.
item.itunes:summary: Listen as archivist Reuben Jackson discusses the Sioux City Ghosts, an African-American traveling baseball team and swing band from the 1930's. Includes accompanying resources for classroom use.
item.itunes:keywords: baseball, music, African American history, 1930's, Smithsonian, American History

item.title: The Man With the Fish On His Back
item.description: Curator Diane Wendt introduces us to one of the stranger objects in the museum's collection and gives an insight into cod liver oil and its ties to the history of brand marketing. Includes accompanying resources for classroom use.
item.itunes:author: Smithsonian National Museum of American History
item.itunes:subtitle: Diane Wendt discusses a very strange object in the museum's collection.
item.itunes:summary: Curator Diane Wendt introduces us to one of the stranger objects in the museum's collection and gives an insight into cod liver oil and its ties to the history of brand marketing. Includes accompanying resources for classroom use.
item.itunes:keywords: medicine, American History, Smithsonian, cod liver, advertising, cod liver oil, fish

item.description: Curator Steven turner discusses the work and shop of Henry Fitz, America's first commercially successful telescope manufacturer. Includes accompanying resources for classroom use.

item.description: Curator William Lawrence Bird talks about the history of American holiday display, from parades such as Macy's and the Tournament of Roses to lavish downtown department store windows, Santa-lands and mechanical displays.

item.title: National History Day
item.description: Learn what it takes to develop a great National History Day project from some museum staff members who have judged the national level in the past. National History Day is an annual competition that engages students in the past through their own well-researched projects.
item.itunes:author: Smithsonian National Museum of American History
item.itunes:summary: Learn what it takes to develop a great National History Day project from some museum staff members who have judged the national level in the past. National History Day is an annual competition that engages students in the past through their own well-researched projects.
item.itunes:keywords: American History, Smithsonian, education, school, history class, National History Day, history project

item.title: Confederate Currency and the Richmond Hoard
item.description: Richard Doty, senior curator of the National Numismatics Collection, shares the story of the "Richmond Hoard", an enormous collection of Confederate currency obtained by the museum. With April, 2011 marking the 150th anniversary of the start of the Civil War, Mr. Doty explains what currency meant to life in the South and how money can be studied to learn about our nationa's past.
item.itunes:author: Smithsonian National Museum of American History
item.itunes:summary: Richard Doty, senior curator of the National Numismatics Collection, shares the story of the "Richmond Hoard", an enormous collection of Confederate currency obtained by the museum. item.itunes:keywords: American History, Smithsonian, education, school, history class, Civil War, currency, money, confederacy, Richmond, numismatics

item.title: Investigating Portraiture
item.description: Shannon Perich, associate cruator at the National Museum of American History, discusses how portraiture can be used in historical research. Shannon presents three historical portraits, describing the historical context of each, while also providing information on how curators and researchers look for clues within historical photography.
item.itunes:author: Smithsonian National Museum of American History
item.itunes:summary: Curator Shannon Perich discusses how portraiture can be used in historical research. Shannon presents three historical portraits, describing the historical context of each, while also providing information on how curators and researchers look for clues within historical photography.
item.itunes:keywords: American History, Smithsonian, education, school, history class, photography, portraits, Civil War, Great Depression, Slavery, Richard Avedon

item.title: HIV and AIDS - Thirty Years Ago
item.description: It's been thirty years since the discovery of HIV and AIDS. In this episode, curator Katherine Ott discusses the history behind the medical and scientific advances that led to this, along with how Americans became aware and accepting of the illness in society.
item.itunes:author: Smithsonian National Museum of American History
item.itunes:summary: It's been thirty years since the discovery of HIV and AIDS. In this episode, curator Katherine Ott discusses the history behind the medical and scientific advances that led to this, along with how Americans became aware and accepting of the illness in society.
item.itunes:keywords: American History, Smithsonian, education, school, history class, HIV, AIDS, science, medicine, diesease

item.title: Crockett Johnson: Art and Math in the Days of Sputnik
item.description: You might remember Crockett Johnson as the writer and illustrator of Harold and the Purple Crayon. In this episode, curator Peggy Kidwell discusses how Johnson's mathematical artwork was inspired by a growing interest amongst Americans in math and science.
item.itunes:author: Smithsonian National Museum of American History
item.itunes:summary: You might remember Crockett Johnson as the writer and illustrator of Harold and the Purple Crayon. In this episode, curator Peggy Kidwell discusses how Johnson's mathematical artwork was inspired by a growing interest amongst Americans in math and science.
item.itunes:keywords: American History, Smithsonian, education, school, history class, math, Crockett Johnson, sputnik, Space Race

item.title: Hurricane Katrina and Collecting from a Disaster
item.description: Six years ago, Hurricane Katrina ravaged the Gulf Coast of the United States. In her wake, a team of curators from the museum set out to collect objects that captured the history of the moment and what it meant to the country. Listen to the late curator David Shayt discuss how and what the museum collected in the immediate aftermath of the devastating storm.
item.itunes:author: Smithsonian National Museum of American History
item.itunes:summary: Six years ago, Hurricane Katrina ravaged the Gulf Coast of the United States. In her wake, a team of curators from the museum set out to collect objects that captured the history of the moment and what it meant to the country. Listen to the late curator David Shayt discuss how and what the museum collected in the immediate aftermath of the devastating storm.
item.itunes:keywords: American History, Smithsonian, hurricane katrina, collecting, museum, disaster, new orleans, gulf coast

item.title: Photography, Portraiture and Identity
item.description: Shannon Perich, a curator in the Photographic Collection, examines three unique photographic portraits, showing how portraiture and the creation of an image between sitter and photographer, can be used to express many ideas beyond that of simply a picture of an individual.
item.itunes:author: Smithsonian National Museum of American History
item.itunes:summary: Shannon Perich, a curator in the Photographic Collection, examines three unique photographic portraits, showing how portraiture and the creation of an image between sitter and photographer, can be used to express many ideas beyond that of simply a picture of an individual.
item.itunes:keywords: American History, Smithsonian, museum, photography, portraiture

item.title: Sugar and Sweeteners in American History
item.description: Museum curator Deborah Warner discusses the role of sugar and various sweeteners in American history. In addition to being a staple in the American diet, sugar's role in our nation's history touches on subjects of science and technology, labor and capital, politics and even popular culture.
item.itunes:author: Smithsonian National Museum of American History
item.itunes:summary: Museum curator Deborah Warner discusses the role of sugar and various sweeteners in American history. In addition to being a staple in the American diet, sugar's role in our nation's history touches on subjects of science and technology, labor and capital, politics and even popular culture.
item.itunes:keywords: American History, Smithsonian, museum, sugar, food history

item.title: Underwater Archaeology and the Museum
item.description: Museum curator Paul Johnston discusses the field of underwater archaeology and how the study of shipwrecks can add to our understanding of many areas and eras in US history.
item.itunes:author: Smithsonian National Museum of American History
item.itunes:summary: Museum curator Paul Johnston discusses the field of underwater archaeology and how the study of shipwrecks can add to our understanding of many areas and eras in US history.

item.title: Japanese Internment and WWII Service
item.description: Curatorial assistant Noriko Sanefuji interviews Grant Ichikawa, a US veteran who enlisted after being relocated to a Japanese internment camp with his family in 1942. Allowed to join the army after a need for interpreters, Mr. Ichikawa served proudly and in 2011, he and other veterans were awarded the Congressional Gold Medal for his service.
item.itunes:author: Smithsonian National Museum of American History
item.itunes:summary: Curatorial assistant Noriko Sanefuji interviews Grant Ichikawa, a US veteran who enlisted after being relocated to a Japanese internment camp with his family in 1942. Allowed to join the army after a need for interpreters, Mr. Ichikawa served proudly and in 2011, he and other veterans were awarded the Congressional Gold Medal for his service.
item.itunes:keywords: American History, Smithsonian, museum, japanese internment, WWII, World War II

item.title: Harlem Globetrotters and Early Professional Basketball
item.description: Curator Eric Jentsch discusses the history of the Harlem Globetrotters, an all-African American basketball team that barnstormed through segregated America to become the world's most recognizable sports team.
item.itunes:author: Smithsonian National Museum of American History
item.itunes:summary: Curator Eric Jentsch discusses the history of the Harlem Globetrotters, an all-African American basketball team that barnstormed through segregated America to become the world's most recognizable sports team.

item.title: Jazz Oral History Program
item.description: Ken Kimery, the executive director of the Smithsonian Jazz Masterworks Orchestra and the Jazz Oral History Project, discusses the Jazz Oral History Project with museum educator Matt Hoffman. Ken explains the history of the program and its importance, as well as gives some tips about how to conduct your own oral history projects.

item.title: Joseph Henry and the History of Weather Prediction in the US
item.description: Like it or not, weather is a major part of our lives, and being able to predict it is extremely useful. Learn about the history of predicting weather in the United States directly from Joseph Henry, one of the Museum Theater Departments historic characters, who played a crucial role in creating a weather prediction service in the United States.
item.itunes:author: Smithsonian National Museum of American History
item.itunes:summary: Like it or not, weather is a major part of our lives, and being able to predict it is extremely useful. item.itunes:keywords: American History, Smithsonian, museum, weather, Joseph Henry

item.title: The Early Modern Olympics
item.description: The first Olympic Games began in 776 BC, but the Olympic Games as we know them today started much later-the 19th century. Learn about the surprising beginnings of the modern Olympic Games and how much has changed since with curator Eric Jentsch.
item.itunes:author: Smithsonian National Museum of American History
item.itunes:subtitle: Eric Jentsch discusses the early modern Olympics.
item.itunes:summary: The first Olympic Games began in 776 BC, but the Olympic Games as we know them today started much later-the 19th century. Learn about the surprising beginnings of the modern Olympic Games and how much has changed since with curator Eric Jentsch.
item.itunes:keywords: olympics, sports, summer olympics, early olympics, early modern olympics, st. louis, 1904 summer olympics, history, American history, museum, Smithsonian

item.title: The Bracero Project
item.description: During World War II, America began its largest experiment with guest Labor, The Mexican Farm Labor Program. Commonly called the bracero program, this little known chapter of American and Mexican history touched the lives of countless men, women, families, and communities. Learn about the bracero program and the Smithsonian's initiative to document it with curator Stephen Velasquez.
item.itunes:author: Smithsonian National Museum of American History
item.itunes:summary: During World War II, America began its largest experiment with guest Labor, The Mexican Farm Labor Program. Commonly called the bracero program, this little known chapter of American and Mexican history touched the lives of countless men, women, families, and communities. Learn about the bracero program and the Smithsonian's initiative to document it with curator Stephen Velasquez.
item.itunes:keywords: American History, Smithsonian, museum, Bracero project

item.description: Curators Harry Rubenstein and Larry Bird discuss their trips to the national nominating conventions, how they collect political memorabilia, what questions they ask, and what advice they have for starting your own collection.

item.description: In this episode of the History Explorer Podcast, Sarah Coffee talks with curator Rayna Green about what we can learn from seemingly simple line drawings about the lives and memories of Plains Indians who lived over 130 years ago.

item.title: Unraveling the Layers of a Wicked Costume
item.description: We're going to go behind the seams to explore the many layers of the Museum's latest acquisition-Elphaba's dress from the Broadway Musical Wicked, which gave a new spin on L. Frank Baum's well known book, The Wonderful Wizard of Oz. You'll hear about the dress's design, importance, and the larger conversations it can lead to from curator Dwight Blocker Bowers, actors Donna Vivino and Tiffany Haas, and the Tony Award winning designer Susan Hilferty.
item.itunes:author: Smithsonian National Museum of American History

item.itunes:keywords: American History, Smithsonian, museum, Wicked, musical, Wizard of Oz, Elphaba, broadway, costumes, Donna Vivino, Tiffany Haas, Susan Hilferty

item.title: Discovering Slack Key Guitar History with Dennis Kamakahi
item.description: What do British cattle and Mexican cowboys have to do with the history of Hawaiian folk music? A lot, as it turns out. Slack Key guitar master Reverend Dennis Kamakahi explains in this episode of History Explorer. The episode features songs Rev. Kamakahi played during a ceremony in which he donated one of his guitars to the museum.
item.itunes:author: Smithsonian National Museum of American History
item.itunes:subtitle: Learn about slack key guitar history from Dennis Kamakahi.

item.title: Women's Military History
item.description: Recently, the US Military officially opened combat positions to women. In this episode of History Explorer, curators Bart Hacker and Margaret Vining discuss the roles that women have played in the military throughout history, their research, and this new policy.
item.itunes:author: Smithsonian National Museum of American History
item.itunes:subtitle: Curators Bart Hacker and Margaret Vining discuss women's role in the military throughout history.

item.description: April is Jazz Appreciation Month! This year, the National Museum of American History is highlighting and celebrating the career of John Levy. In this episode of History Explorer, Smithsonian Jazz Masterworks Orchestra Director Ken Kimery discusses John Levy's story and legacy.

item.title: Fraternal Orders
item.description: Often incorporating aspects ritual and secrecy, fraternal orders are voluntary associations of men and women that date back to the early 18th century. Tim Winkle discusses fraternal orders and his research on a particular object in the Museum collection that led him to some interesting discoveries.
item.itunes:author: Smithsonian National Museum of American History
item.itunes:subtitle: Curator Tim Winkle discusses fraternal orders.
item.itunes:summary: Often incorporating aspects ritual and secrecy, fraternal orders are voluntary associations of men and women that date back to the early 18th century. item.title: The Shocking History of Benjamin Franklin
item.description: Benjamin Franklin is one of the founding fathers of the United States; he is also widely considered one of the founding fathers of electrical science. Steve Madewell of the Lemelson Center of Invention and Innovation discusses Franklins pursuits in electrical science and the impact that his work in science had on his career as a politician and statesman.
item.itunes:author: Smithsonian National Museum of American History
item.itunes:subtitle: Learn about Ben Franklin, the scientist, from Steve Madewell.
item.itunes:summary: Benjamin Franklin is one of the founding fathers of the United States; he is also widely considered one of the founding fathers of electrical science. item.itunes:keywords: Benjamin Franklin, science, scientist, electrical science, Franklin, Ben Franklin, national museum of american history, history, American history, museum, Smithsonian

item.title: Uncle Sam
item.description: Whether you've seen him on the cover of a poster, as the central character in a comic, or leading a parade, Uncle Sam is a clear embodiment of the United States. Was Uncle Sam ever a real person? Where did the idea come from? Natalie Elder in our Armed Forces History Division answers these questions and more in this month's episode of History Explorer.
item.itunes:author: Smithsonian National Museum of American History
item.itunes:subtitle: Learn about Uncle Sam from Natalie Elder.

item.title: Courtland Cox on This Generation's Challenge
item.description: Freedom Summer veteran Courtland Cox discusses his work in the civil rights movement, the relationship between the work of Freedom Summer and the recent voter registration requirements, and emphasizes that the challenge of this generation of young people will be the fight for equal access to quality education.
item.itunes:author: Smithsonian National Museum of American History
item.itunes:subtitle: Freedom Summer veteran Courtland Cox discusses his work in the civil rights movement, the relationship between the work of Freedom Summer and the recent voter registration requirements, and emphasizes that the challenge of this generation of young people will be the fight for equal access to quality education.
item.itunes:summary: Freedom Summer veteran Courtland Cox discusses his work in the civil rights movement, the relationship between the work of Freedom Summer and the recent voter registration requirements, and emphasizes that the challenge of this generation of young people will be the fight for equal access to quality education.
item.itunes:keywords: civil rights, SNCC, Black History Month, Courtland Cox, activism, national museum of american history, history, American history, museum, Smithsonian
